title: Will Prayut Chan-o-cha cease to be the prime minister of Thailand before 23 April 2021?
preds: Not enough political pressure for him to leave

Jatuporn calls for unity in seeking Prayut's removal - The Phuket News
https://www.thephuketnews.com/jatuporn-calls-for-unity-in-seeking-prayut-removal-79569.php
Mon, 05 Apr 2021 07:00:00 GMT
Small protest, no change in forecast. All quiet on the reddit.com/r/Thailand/ front, though some of the posts can be pretty funny (i.e. https://www.reddit.com/r/Thailand/comments/mpbq4j/prayuth_unlocked_his_golden_skin_after_being_an/)

Currently, the Thai government has chosen to intensify police response to the protests instead of compromising with the protests. This is a clear indication by the Prime Minister and his government that they will not concede and give up power. The Prime Minister has reiterated that he views the protests as illegal and thus would not warrant him stepping down from power. Prayut is also a staunch pro-monarchy leader, and because the protesters are criticizing the monarchy, him resining due to those protesters would hurt his image.

Considering the timeline of this issue - that the coup happened in 2014, Prayut Chan-o-cha was sworn in in June 2020, and student protests have been happening since August 2020 - it has been a long timeline, and I don’t predict that there is a high likelihood of this changing in the next month and a half. He was even acquitted by court in December 2020 after being brought up on ethical charges (Tanakasempipat, P., & Thepgumpanat, P., 2020). Tanakasempipat, P., & Thepgumpanat, P. (2020, December 2). Thai PM found not guilty in conflict of interest case. Reuters. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-thailand-protests/thai-pm-found-not-guilty-in-conflict-of-interest-case-idUSKBN28C13G
Probability is vanishingly small given the timeframe

"In Thailand, although the Siamese Revolution of 1932 marked the start of a Thai democratic tradition, instability and conflicts over political power between the bureaucrats and military were incessant. Coups became a frequent means to seize power, and democratic election results were often diminished. There were 13 successful coups, the most recent of which took place in 2014, led by General Prayut Chan-o-cha, who is in charge of the current government. Unlike other constitutional monarchies like the U.K. or Japan, the Thai monarchy has a robust role in domestic politics. Hence, the military junta in Thailand has relied on the royal sovereign’s approval as one of the sources of its legitimacy, and democracy was sidelined as a core value. Because public demands do not necessarily challenge the legitimacy of the government, calls for democracy were more easily overlooked."
https://thediplomat.com/2021/03/can-southeast-asia-follow-south-koreas-democratization-model/
It may happen, but even though protests intensified in the past few days, it's unlikely to happen by 23 April 2021.

Monarchy has cracked down on protests and despite popular discontent Prayut Chan-o-cha has maintained his hold on power. If he was not ousted by the protests last year it is unlikely that he will cease to be prime minister in the near future. The short timespan of this question also decreases the likelihood of the answer being 'Yes.'

Censure Debate Over Prayut’s Handling of Virus Slated for Feb. 16 - Khaosod English

Mon, 25 Jan 2021 11:30:00 GMT

Base Rate:
Once a military or Khana Ratsadon Prime Minister lasts longer than a few days in office, they serve for a relatively lengthy term. The average military/Khana Ratsadon PM term is calculated below:  Phraya Phahonphonphayuhasena (Khana Ratsadon): 5 years, 178 days; 2,003 days
Plaek Phibunsongkhram (Khana Ratsadon): 5 years, 229 days; 2,054 days
Sarit Thanarat (Military): 5 years, 49 days; 1,874 days
Thanom Kittikachorn (Military): 9 years, 309 days; 3,594 days
Kriangsak Chamanan (Military): 2 years, 113 days; 843 days
Prem Tinsulanonda (Military): 8 years, 154 days 3,074 days  13,442/6 = 2,240
Average term length for Military/Khana Ratsadon PM is around 2,240 days, or 6 years and 50 days.  PM Chan-o-cha has served as PM since 21 August 2014, so for him to serve until April 23rd of 2021 would be well within the average length of 2,240 days.  Thus, I'm confident with using the low GJP crowd forecast of 3% for Chan-o-cha to lose his PM position before 23 April 2021 as the base rate.  Base Rate: 3%  Adjustments:
Pro-democracy, anti-Chan-o-cha protests have been a regular occurrence in 2020. As the Independent wrote in October 2020, "For a major part of 2020, anti-government protests have been going on in Thailand. But for the past few months, they have escalated with protesters demanding a new constitution, the resignation of prime minister Prayut and a reduction in the powers of a monarchy which is still much-revered by older generations." I believe this warrants a 5% increase.
+5%  Total adjustments: 5%  Final rate: 8%

Sat, 19 Dec 2020 00:15:14 GMT Government corruption in Thailand hit a record high under the post-coup National Council for Peace (NCPO) junta, lead by Prayut Chan-o-cha. Thailand’s National Anti-Corruption Commission released a report on Thursday. Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha, who led the NCPO junta after staging the 2014 coup, was quick to playdown the report. Saying the report’s findings mostly drew mostly on complaints of corruption rather than proven cases. He said that people would always try to cheat the system, but said he did not want to reveal the names of the culprits. Instead, he ordered the his Office to publicize the achievements of his government. Above all to show how “well it had served the people”. *** UN rights office calls on Thailand to amend royal insult law

The current crop of demonstrators wants three things:  this guy to resign, a new constitution, and curbs on royal powers.  Throwing Prayut off the sleigh to the wolves is the only one that might happen this time, and it would be fairly easy and painless for his loyal friends and colleagues to do.  Coming up a bit, for a while.

Worth keeping an eye on. I’m staying low at 1% given I don’t know there’s a credible successor, but things could change quickly. From the Economist
“Meanwhile, the prime minister, Prayuth Chan-ocha, who led the coup in 2014 in which the army (ostensibly in defence of the monarchy) seized power, grows less conciliatory by the day. In particular, a draconian law against “insulting” the monarchy has been dusted off and used against more than a score of activists. Mr Prayuth’s star, admittedly, is waning with the king, not least for letting the protests wax so dramatically. But if Mr Prayuth is dismissed as a scapegoat, it will surely be because King Vajiralongkorn wants his successor to take a harder line.”

Lots of pressure within country. Difficult to say how it will be released. From the Economist 	
“Thailand’s political temperature keeps rising. This week pro-democracy protesters clashed with police and royalists in front of parliament. Police used tear-gas and water cannon (around 50 people were injured and a handful treated for gunshot wounds). Inside, MPs debated constitutional reforms—including curbs on royal powers and the army’s dominant role in politics, such as the students demand. The government has a majority and, being royalist and pro-army, it rejected progressive proposals to change the charter that it wrote in 2017. Parliament looks likely to establish a face-saving committee that will fiddle with the constitution but keep the old guard in power. Ultra-royalists continue calling for a coup to protect the monarchy. High-living King Vajiralongkorn remains constitutionally “enthroned in a position of revered worship”. But under his reign, the monarchy’s hold on people’s imagination is much reduced. Today Prayuth Chan-ocha, the prime minister, warned protesters the state would use “all the pertaining laws” against them. The country is entering risky territory“

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-thailand-protests/thousands-of-thai-protesters-call-for-removal-of-prime-minister-idUSKBN27U0A4 If I were the Thai monarchy or military, which by the way is not the case, I would be looking for a cushy job to move this lad to, at least for a while.  The demonstrations have been mostly focused on him personally, presumably so as not to trigger the laws against raising an eyebrow at the king.  He can become the ambassador to someplace easy and comfy until the frenzy dissipates, and then go back to his old gig if he wants it.  Or he could meet with a tragic accident.  Stay tuned.

1.  Last general election was in 2019.  They are (supposed to be) held every three years.  This places the next general election in 2022.  
2.  40% of dictators will suffer an election loss and 12% who suffer an election loss will actually step down (https://oefresearch.org/think-peace/when-dictators-lose-elections).  
3.  With no election before 2022 and the statistics of 12% actually stepping down, this leads an outside view that is a low probability.
4.  Protests don't often result in regime change (admit I could have dug more for a true base rate):  https://www.pri.org/stories/2019-12-30/protests-rocked-world-2019
5.  Inside view: protests in Thailand are widespread but the "personality"of the PM doesn't lead to a resignation.

I've never worked in a country where monarchist sentiment was so strong (and I'm a Brit!). As long as the king stands behind him, it seems extremely unlikely that these protests will weaken Prayut Chan-o-cha's position. So I'm making my prediction solely on the short-term possibility that a corruption scandal or similar will force him out.

Protesters are approaching is less likely to create a problem for PM than if they were directly going after him. MY prior is 14.7% (updated for passage of time), and my case specific probability is 5%. 75/25 weighting, to get to 12%.  https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/nov/08/police-fire-water-cannon-thai-pro-democracy-protesters

Really a Military and Government controlled country? Inocencio (2020). October 26, stated that:

"They always do that, because you have to understand that all the television stations in Thailand are under control by the national broadcasting and telecommunication commission, which can be influenced by the government," said Voice TV national anchor Teerat Ratanasevi. "We have the police in front of our office every day"(Para 13). A Thai court ordered the online broadcaster to suspend operations on October 20, alleging the dissemination of "false information." "But what we really did in the field is we just put our camera live to let our audiences see what's going on. We don't have any anchor. We don't do any live programming. So we wondered what we did wrong, why they tried to shut us down," Ratanasevi said. Voice TV's suspension was reviewed, then lifted one day later (Para 13-16).

Trimming a point with the passage of time. And further to my last forecast, this PM has been in the role since the 2014 coup, it doesn't appear (to an Australian with google) that he has lost the support of the royal family or the military. Add to this the last coup (according to wiki - https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2014_Thai_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat) "began" in Nov 2013 with anti-government protests, and ended in May 2014 with the overthrow government. Following this time line, if we are to see another PM Prayut due to forces outside of the government, it's unlikely to happen before April 1st.
He seems to be hanging on by a thread, losing military support, and king might throw him under the bus. Potential crackdown on protesters is less likely than coup at this moment.

I've touched on this previously. We have started shifting into an era where politicians do not step down.  I sited examples from contemporary Australian politics where an incident held no immediate repercussions after a couple weeks of bad press, is comparable to an incident ~20 years ago which resulted in a ministers resignation from office.  This is in a country that scores reasonably on various freedoms/corruptions indices.  Unless there's another coup, he's unlikely to go
Seems unlikely on an initial read. Seized power in military coup in 2014, won elections in 2019 (though it was close and may have been unfair), and no elections scheduled in near future.

Collecting the logic all in one place. My prior is based on three different criteria.  1. First, the statistic on peaceful protests being successful about 53% of the time, from @LokiOdinevich. [Our findings show that major nonviolent campaigns have achieved success 53 percent of the time, compared with 26 percent for violent resistance campaigns (https://www.belfercenter.org/sites/default/files/legacy/files/IS3301_pp007-044_Stephan_Chenoweth.pdf]. For that I'm assuming a 1.5 year half-life, so that translates to a 21.7% odds over a 6 month period.
2. The statistic on military regimes attrition of 90% over 10 years (https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1642040). I'm assuming a memoryless process (i.e. if youre in power it doesn't mean youre conditionally more likely to decline, which I think makes sense since sometimes it does mean your closer to the ends and sometimes it just means you have entrenched power). That translates to 10.5% odds.
3. My own search that Thailand has had on average a change of power every 2 years. Translates to 15.5% odds.  So that prior, on average, is 15.9% (average of all three measures). Call that the outside-in view.  For the inside view, I don't have much of an edge. I have questions and stray thoughts
- protests can persist for a long time without a change (e.g. I would have thought Carrie Lam would be out in Hong Kong). 
- more broadly, who would replace the PM? Are there other concessions that could be offered 
- secularly, I worry about democracy globally and in Asia. 
- this overthrow is 100% something that will be internal, I don't see any outside power helping one way or the other. With perhaps the exception of Germany telling the king he needs to leave.  I am evaluating the comments here and I see credible perspectives on both sides, with the more credible views drifting a little bit higher. Ian Bremer says the PM is "massively in danger", while the monarchy isn't. https://www.gzeromedia.com/in-60-seconds/world2/thailands-monarchy-nigeria-protests-bolivias-new-president-covid-latest. Also some other credible looking forecasts (wide dispersion) are a bit higher. I'll call the Bremer/expert opinion 50%.  My own discretionary opinion, which isn't really stress-tested, is that the protesters made a mistake by going after the monarchy. If they directly went for the prime minister, then it would make sacrificing the PM an easy move for both the military and the king. But since they went after the monarchy initially, if the PM is sacrificed then it's a show of weakness and who's to say the Monarchy isn't next. Call these odds 10%.  I weigh the prior heavily because of the historical data. 75% weight for the prior, 25% weight for the inside view (which I'll give the expert opinion a 2:1 weight view vs mine). That leaves me with 75%*16% + 17%*50% + 8% * 10% = 19.4%.  So this is a tiny revision, but wanted to put my logic out there. Also curious what indicators are worth watching or what objective media sources might be able to indicate if the facts are changing.  I'm trying to think of what factual indicators I'll follow to update my probabilities.

Staying fairly high on this.  This guy is wildly unpopular.  The king is increasingly looked at askance.  He and his bedfellows in the military (the king has many bedfellows, mostly not fellows,  but the military are the ones holding him up)  will not want the PM's negatives to rub off on them any more than necessary.  If things don't calm down, which they show little sign of doing, they may decide to throw him off the sleigh to the wolves in the hope of buying themselves some more time.  This will probably work for a while longer. (@alexandemeister, this is probably more responsive to the question you actually asked than my initial bloviation.  Sorry.)
Going up a little bit after discussion.

As rather common with these questions on those in power, the prior should start with nothing will change. Read a few of the articles... I don't see anything that sways me away from that prior at the moment. Unfortunately doesn't sound like a great situation though.

He has the army and the king on his side, since 2014. It’s not like in a regime up since 1238, which the people is overall fond of (ok,ok a few glinches lately), they don’t know how to handle some protester. He has the king thrust and that’s enough. Protests are somewhat listened to from high up, but that’s all. Pretty much what Will happen in the US if Trump manages to stay😬. Turnover occurred in different circumstances. Decreasing soon.

Updating my base rate. If the average turnover is every two years, the base rate is 1- exp(ln(0.5)*t/2), where t is measured in years. That means a base rate of 16%. There is an awful lot of turmoil right now, but until I can see the parliamentary path for the toppling of this regime, sticking with the base rate.

Thailand has a history of political turmoil. The Prime Minister will not resign and his recent decision to move two military forces directly under his command indicate he'll go at great lengths to maintain his position.

This is interesting, because Prayut's power comes mainly from his association to the military, but the one who has backing among the people is the king. The king could replace him, e.g., by calling for new elections.   group's Facebook pag"You can go after Prayut but don't touch the monarchy," one member wrote on the royaliste. https://www.bangkokpost.com/thailand/politics/2008003/yellow-shirts-defend-parliament-from-anti-government-protesters Across town, protesters returned to Ratchaprasong intersection to voice their demands. Protest leaders have said if Gen Prayut is sincere in calling on all sides to take one step back, he should quit his post. Some royalist leaders have disavowed violence. For them, defending the monarchy is not political because the monarchy is above politics. "We cannot assume that General Prayut will give in so easily, especially now that the King is signalling his full support," said Mr Termsak Chalermpalanupap, at the ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute in Singapore.

In retrospect one could have predicted this one much earlier. The Thais hate their king, who does not even live in the country (they loved the old king, his father). With tourism put to a halt anyways (due to Covid19), on which many people depend for their income, it is the perfect opportunity to try to get rid of the king (and with him Prayut Chan-o-cha - whose whole legitimacy is based on the king's backing), with lower personal economic cost.

The base rate for prime minister turnover is about 25%, based on there being 10 Thai prime ministers since 2000, so that’s one every two years and a 25% chance over 6 months. There was a general election in 2019 as well. There are conflicting other factors - such as the issues mentioned in the question, but also that he was installed by a military coup and so may not give up power easily. Will research it more, but for now sticking with base rate.

https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-54675173 ... Monarchy seldom gets involved, this is a clear indication of closing ranks and the barricades going up. The students want (not unfairly) to change the entire political system of Thailand ... The establishment are not going to go quietly. Possible fatal clashes incoming.
Baseline - Don't know... Need to do research...
While protests are ongoing, nothing leads me to believe Prayut Chan-o-cha will resign or be forced out in the immediate future.

I've been browsing the literature a little bit.  > Our findings show that major nonviolent campaigns have achieved success 53  percent  of  the  time,  compared  with  26  percent  for  violent resistance campaigns (https://www.belfercenter.org/sites/default/files/legacy/files/IS3301_pp007-044_Stephan_Chenoweth.pdf; unreliable source but useful as an upper bound, also doesn't mention timelines) https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1642040 (available on sci-hub): Terrible theoretical paper, empirical findings should be ok, suggests <10% attrition rate of repressive regimes within the first two years of protests (figure 2).  http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.122.7981&rep=rep1&type=pdf : Sadly non-replicable; states its results in terms of expected lifetime, not in terms of attrition rate.  CIA Factbook: https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/th.html; nothing much to say.  http://www.princeton.edu/~piirs/Dictatorships042508/Magaloni%20&%20Wallace%20-%20Loyalty,%20Protest,%20&%20Authoritarian%20Survival.pdf (Figure 1): Suggests 90% attrition within the first 10 years for military regimes. In particular, eyeballing the graph, for those which have survived 6 years, 10% yearly attrition rate. On the inside view,

https://www.theamericanconservative.com/articles/thailands-military-dictatorship-endangered-by-impassioned-students/
Cato Institute author
https://www.reddit.com/r/Thailand/comments/jfvsyh/thailands_military_dictatorship_endangered_by/ After the nominal reestablishment of democracy, Prayuth is still in power. However, he has lost influence over the armed forces with his ascension in nominally civilian politics. Prayuth shares power with King Maha Vajiralongkorn, the former playboy crown prince who spends much of his time in Germany counting his billions and enjoying members of his harem, and the new military hierarchy, in which hardliners allied with the king are ascendant. Now tens of thousands of Thais are taking to the streets in protest against this self-serving triumvirate. Thailand was an important U.S. military ally during the Vietnam War. Once known as Siam, it remained independent as Western imperialist powers gobbled up colonies nearby. In 1932, a military coup overturned the absolute monarchy. Since then, Thai politics have tended toward the tempestuous, with 12 coups and 20 constitutions. Prayuth used bodies controlled by military henchmen—250 junta-appointed members of the Senate, the junta-selected Election Commission, and the junta-chosen Constitutional Court—to gerrymander districts, outlaw opposition parties, file charges against hostile politicians, and steal MPs from regime opponents. In today’s Thai system, democracy is but a façade, acting as lip gloss for the dictatorship in place of the pig. More than 80 protest leaders have been arrested. Gatherings of more than five people have been banned. Riot police have been deployed. Roads have been blocked. Public transit has been closed. The increasingly desperate authorities mulled suspending the app Telegram and censoring television coverage. The regime threatened two-year jail terms for simply posting a selfie at a rally or visiting a protest website. Major General Yingyos Thepjumnong, speaking for the police and thus the junta, declared: “It is like you are taking your own evidence of disobeying the emergency decree” But still the demonstrators came. Protesters will not be satisfied by platitudes. As one student told the New York Times: “The goal is to change the whole political system, including the monarchy and the prime minister.”

 The new king grabbed control of heretofore public assets worth $30 to $40 billion, asserted personal command over two Bangkok-based military units, and spends most of his time at a German resort accompanied by a retinue of servants and concubines. An unnamed aide told The Economist that his priorities are to “bike, f*ck, eat. He does only those three things.” 

https://www.bangkokpost.com/opinion/opinion/2006643/history-not-on-the-side-of-gen-prayut

https://www.reddit.com/r/Thailand/ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prayut_Chan-o-cha
During the political crisis that began in November 2013 and involved protests against the caretaker government of Yingluck, Prayut claimed that the army was neutral[10] and would not launch a coup. However, in May 2014, Prayut staged a military coup against the government and assumed control of the country as NCPO leader.[11] He later issued an interim constitution granting himself sweeping powers and giving himself amnesty for staging the coup.[12] In August 2014, an unelected military-dominated national legislature appointed him as Prime Minister.[13][14] *** tl;dr: Prayut Chan-o-cha seems like he has all the levers of power (police, military, monarchy seems absent, senate, political elite). I'm reminded of the recent situation in Belarus, or the attempted revolution in Catalunya, which were quashed. Maybe 40%, and 50% when I take into account the aggregate.  *** I also have a new toy to play around with, Squiggle, which lets me determine the optimal probability decay schedule for a given initial probability; see explanation here: https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/j8o6sgRerE3tqNWdj/adjusting-probabilities-for-the-passage-of-time-using, or copy the code below here: https://5f3973242bc7c000071f50a7--distracted-mirzakhani-b102f4.netlify.app/dist-builder (ctrl+i to start editing) total_probability=0.5 ## Until 23 April 2021 
period_probability_function(epsilon)=1-(1-total_probability)^(1/epsilon)
probability_decayed(t, total_time, period_probability) = 1-(1-period_probability)^(total_time-t) ## Monthly decomposition
total_time_monthly=6 # months until 23 April 2021
monthly_probability=period_probability_function(total_time_monthly)
probability_decayed_monthly(t)=probability_decayed(t, total_time_monthly, monthly_probability) 
probability_decayed_monthly
## probability_decayed_monthly(0.25) ## after 1 week = 0.25 months.
